import React, {Component} from "react" import styled from 'styled-components' class Divvy extends Component { render(){ return (

Divvy Case Study

Designing an app that will encourage Gen Z users to keep track of money usage


Introduction
Context

This design project was done as a final evaluation for my Launch UX course where I was taught basic UX principles and had the ability to practice them alingside my peers. I collaborated with Tien Tran, a friend and another student in the course, to bring this idea to life entirely remotely which was another interesting aspect to this project. This case study will take you through this process and summarize what we learned as realatively new designers.

Problem Statement

"How might we design a web and mobile app that allows Gen Z college students to create a monthly budget and track their spending?" Our problems statement was one that we were able to pick out of 4 others to complete this project. We chose this one since it was dear to our hearts as Gen Z students entering the world of adulthood and soon having to handle our own budgets.


Research
Observing the current market

When thinking about how we wanted to approach this issue we looked first for inspiration and how companies were solving this problem currently. There are many apps that have been made to help users better keep track of their money, we deciding to focus on Buddy and EveryDollar. We picked these apps because it had similar functionality and aesthertics to what we wanted in out final app. The problem was that we could not directly use these apps as a template as they were not catered to out specific user class which in this case is Gen Z college students. We mainly used these apps as a reference to certain technical functionality and actions that may be applicable in our case.

User interviews

While it is clear that we are the exact target user for our problem statement, it was still important to separate our preferences and ideas of what a good budgeting app can be to get a wider idea of what Gen Z students think. We conducted both ethnographic and non-directed interviews from students ranging from 19-22 as well as recently graduated alumni as we thought it help us get a sense of what a person who has already transistioned into the real world financially wouldve wanted help with through this product.

Ethnographic: we conducted these using the two apps mentioned earlier, Buddy and EveryDollar. We wanted to see how our target users navigate these apps and which actions were intutive. Ultimately we wated to learn which features were benificial for us to learn from and which features we could improve on. Questions: Buddy mobile app Can you show me how you would create a new budget? Can you add random numbers for the categories you use in real life? Can you remove categories that don’t apply to you? Can you add me as a member of this budget? Can you show me how you would log a transaction? Can you change income to 3,000? Can you flip to a different week? What features did you find most useful? Would you or would you not use this app and why? Every dollar app Could you show me how to make a new budget for August? Could you walk me through the process of adding an item to the food category? Could you walk me through submitting a transaction? Could you show me how you would change your income amount? Could you show me how you would delete an item? Could you show me how you would make the church item a monthly item? Could you walk me through how you would set a due date for an item.


Wireframe

Prototype

Usability testing

Takeways
); } } export default Divvy;
